loans.name: Loriza

texts.en:
Loriza L. is 46 years old and a good mother to her two children, who have graduated from college. She is married to her kind-hearted husband, Jose L., a sales representative of Greenlife. They live in Morong, Rizal, an attractive place, . 

Loriza sells Greenlife products. She plans to use this loan of Php 25,000 to expand her business and get involved in other businesses for supplementary profits. She will use this loan to buy Greenlife coffee (Php 5,900.00), Greenlife juice (Php 4,000.00), Greenlife syrup (Php 7,700.00) and Greenlife assorted products (Php 7,400.00). During her two years as a member of ASHI, Loriza has performed very well and ASHI trusts her to repay her loans.

This loan will enable her to finally achieve her dreams in life: to have a winning business, the best in life, and a happy family as well. She is very thankful to ASHI for their continuous support of her dreams. She also hoping that, with the help of ASHI, she can provide a sustainable life for her family and enable them to have a comfortable house to live in.

loans.use: To buy Greenlife products to sell

loans.name: Aniscia

texts.en:
Aniscia B. is from the village of Guiwano in Panalsalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old. Aniscia is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Aniscia sells fish and shrimp. Aniscia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Aniscia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aniscia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her fish business. This will be Aniscia's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is popularly called Mama Esosa in her community in Benin City, Edo state. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to improve her business and lift herself out of poverty. Her husband is a farmer. Juliet is a mother of five children and she is 48 years old.  She has been in this business for a long time. 

LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Juliet is requesting a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria D. is from the village of Labinay in Ozamiz City. She is 58 years old. Gloria is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Gloria grows and sells bananas. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Gloria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Gloria's third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.name: Lien's Group

texts.en:
Lien T. T. ( id: 010117050056) is 27 years old. She sells aluminum and glass doors. She lives with her husband and child. She has a monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND. She has been a member of SEDA for two years and repays her loans on time. This time, she wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($270 USD) to invest in her business. Her group consists of:
  • Hoa T. N. ( id: 010117050048) is 39 years old. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($270 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.
  • Phuong T. N. ( id: 010117050054) is 34 years old. She wants to borrow 4.578.000 VND ($245 USD) to buy and sell iron scrap.
  • Nhai T. T. ( id: 010117050055) is 44 years old. She wants to borrow 4.142.000 VND ($225 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.

loans.name: Chroek

texts.en: Chroek S. is a 43 years old and lives in the middle of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She was married, but divorced her husband years ago. She has two children who are not longer in school and currently work sewing clothes for a garment industry. Chroek S. earns her daily income by providing a small loans with stable repayment schedules to people who are her neighbors in the village. The family’s living situation is difficult since their house is old and needs repair. Because of that, Chroek S. requests a loan of $350 to be used to repair her old house.

loans.use: To repair her old house

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace sells garri (cassava flakes) at retail prices to her customers. The demand for her garri (cassava flakes) is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. Garri is an essential commodity in Nigeria and it can be eaten with Nigerian soup or with groundnut and dried fish. She is 53 years old and married with five children. Her children are excelling in their school work. Her husband is a plumber. She is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Grace sells her garri at the market in Benin City, Edo state. She needs a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more garri to sell. She hopes to add the sales of yam, plantains and rice to her business in the future. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more garri (cassava flakes) to sell

loans.name: Varsenik

texts.en:
Varsenik G. is 48 years old. She is married and has four children. Three of her children are married. Her youngest child is school-aged and lives with her parents in Ijevan. 

Several years ago, Varsenik worked as a shop assistant. Since 2003, she has owned her own business. She rents a shop where she sells food and household goods. Varsenik’s husband, son, and daughter-in-law help her with her business. With the proceeds from her business, they meet their family’s needs. Varsenik’s shop has many clients, thanks to her pleasant treatment. One of her buyers expressed his thanks in rhyme! 

Varsenik seeks a loan of  700.000 AMD loan to increase the assortment of beverage foods in her shop. With the income, she intends to buy dining room furniture for her house.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of beverage foods for her shop

loans.name: Jane

To make a living, Jane sells new clothing to local community members. Jane has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from these activities.

Jane joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jane is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Jane's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Cecilia is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Cecilia grows and sells rices. Cecilia earns approximately PHP 30,000 for every crop (every four months).

Cecilia is requesting a new loan of PHP 12000 to purchase fertilizer, such as manure. This will be Cecilia's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition.

loans.name: Arcelita

texts.en:
Arcelita M. is from the village of Talakag in Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Arcelita is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Arcelita sells  cooked bananas and other snacks to eat during the day. Arcelita is just starting this business.

In 2009, Arcelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arcelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that she used to buy ingredients for her snacks. Arcelita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to buy more raw ingredients to sell. This will be Arcelita's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia is 48 years old and lives in the island of Binangonan, an attractive province of Rizal. She and her husband have three children. Judy Ann, 12 years old, is a high school student. Jeremie, 11 years old, and Jericho, 9 years old, are both in elementary grades. She is married to Hilario, a 52-year-old construction worker (laborer) and a supportive husband.

In 1997, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap Inc.) a microfinance institution and KIVA field partner in the Philippines. Amelia makes and sells food. She has been in business for more than 10 years. She believes that her proposed loan of Php 20,000.00 will be a big help and will contribute to the growth of her business. She will use all of the loans funds to buy rice, sugar, and an electric coconut grinder for her business. She will also start raising hogs for additional income.  

Amelia dreams of sending her children to school and hopes that will complete a degree in college. She believes that poor families need support so that they can change their standard of living and build beautiful houses for their families to live. When she joined ASHI, she had only a "bahay kubo" (a small house made of bamboo) but with the benefit of loans and the support of ASHI in their lives, their small house of bamboo has become big one made of hollow blocks. Half of her dreams have been gradually achieved, but she is still dreaming about completing them. Amelia is a positive and optimistic mother who knows that she will overcome all challenges and achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, and an electric coconut grinder, and to start a hog-raising business

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing is married and has three children. She is 48 years old. Her husband works as a security man at a private firm in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She sells soft drinks and pure water at retail prices to her customers. She wants to change her line of business because of the high season. She hopes to sell baby items like clothes, shoes, bags and cream. She says that this business is highly profitable. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby items to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby items to sell

loans.name: Voeung

texts.en: Voeung S., 45, has been an internal staff at a Cambodian Port for more than four years and currently gets a salary of $160 per month. Her husband works with her at the same location. (Voeung S. was not available at that time, so her husband is in the picture instead.) She has two teenage children who go to school. Since the family's current income is not adequate to meet their need, Mrs. Voeung S. wants to generate extra income by investing as a grocery seller.  However, she does not yet have money yet to start the new business. Therefore, she would like to seek a loan of $1200 which she will build a grocery store and then buy a larger quantity of grocery inventory to begin selling.

loans.use: To build a grocery store and then buy a larger quantity of grocery inventory

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. S. and her family live in a small wooden house, located in a rural area of Phnom Penh City. S., 34, helps provide for her two children by working as a garment worker. Two of her children are still single, living in the family home and are dependent on her income. She is married to Phally, 45, who earns a living as a motor-taxi driver. The whole family's living conditions are not good because their house too old and small for them. Because of this, S. has decided to request a loan on Kiva to be used to repair her old house.

loans.use: To repair her old house

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun C., age 30, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and she also makes and sells brooms at the local market, earning approximately US $2.00 each day. Her husband, Chak Chamnan, who appears in the photograph, is a motor-taxi driver who makes US $7.00 of profit each day. They have four children; two are students and two are too young to attend school. 

Bun makes her brooms from a type of long grass that grows in the forest. She told to a loan officer that she needs to spend around US $30.00 on food and US $15.00 on utilities. Bun C. is asking for a loan of US $500.00 to purchase cows to assist her in her farm work.

loans.use: To purchase cows for her farming business

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona D. is from the city of Biray in Ozamiz City. She is 34 years old. Chona is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Chona sells vegetables in the local community. Chona has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Chona joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chona is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Chona's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en: Janeth is 40 years old and is married, with six children. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. Her husband is a carpenter. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She sells foodstuffs like plantain, yam, garri and rice at retail prices. She hopes to be a major foodstuff distributor in the future. Janeth is a very hard working woman and she loves her business and family so much. With the profits she makes from her sales, she supports her husband in paying their children’s school fees. She is requesting for a loan to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nasera

texts.en:
Nasera Z. sells bread and charcoal from her home. She is requesting a loan to buy more baking flour so she can make more bread and cakes to sell.  Nasera is 40 years old and is widowed. She has 6 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy baking flour for bread and cakes

loans.name: Gina's Group

texts.en: Gina G. is from the village of Bitag Pequeño Baggao,Cagayan. She is 35 years old. Gina is the group leader of a 19-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Gina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Gina runs a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Gina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Gina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is 42 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a bricklayer and he also supports the home. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. 

Stella sells groceries at retail prices. She hopes to add the sales of cooking oil to her business. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs and necessities of her family members. She hopes to be a major cooking-oil distributor in the future. She needs a loan of 40,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim S. is 24 years old and lives with his wife in the Takeo province. He works at a security company and makes $7 a day. His wife stays at home and raises pigs. On average, she earns $4 of profit a day. 

Sim S. would like to take out a loan of $800 to purchase rice. He will purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning a profit. He is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase his income and raise his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Sell rice

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria M. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol at home and is requesting a loan to stock other items like sodas, beer, and wine to sell. Victoria is 40 years old and is married to a husband that is a mechanic. She has four children that go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock sodas, beer, and wine to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Juliet is 45 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a business man and also a commercial driver. She sells clothes, shoes, beads, jewelries and cooking utensils at retail prices to make a living. Juliet has been in this business for a very long time and has no regrets about her business. 

Juliet needs a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more jewelry, clothes and cooking utensils to sell in this festive season. She hopes to own a super market in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more beads, jewelry, clothes and cooking utensils to sell

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Khut P., 45, is married and lives with four children in the Takeo province. She sells vegetables at the local market to earn approximately US$2 of profit every day while her husband grows watermelon. On average, he earns about US$1 a day. Four of the children are students. Khut P. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike so that she can transport vegetables to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables.

loans.name: Chen

texts.en: Chen C., 29, is married and resides with her husband in the Takeo province. She stays at home raising pigs to earn a living and is able to make about US$1.50 of profit a day while her husband is a construction foreman. On average, he makes US$3 per day. This couple has three children, two of who are students, and one is too young to attend. Chen C. would like to take out a loan of US$400 to raise chickens.

loans.use: To buy chickens to raise.

loans.name: El

texts.en: El M. was born in 1970 and has been living in Phnom Penh City for years. In the past, she worked as a garment worker in a garment factory. Presently, she doesn’t work at the factory because she is caring for her children and home. Her business now is to help her husband with his fishing business on the public lakes.  They typically earn $7 per day to support their family. El M. will use this loan to purchase a motor to connect to her fishing boat so she can reach the fish more quickly.

loans.use: To purchase a motor for a fishing boat

loans.name: Varn

texts.en: Varn N., 48, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She grows and sells vegetables at the local market to earn approximately US$3 of profit every day while her husband is a laborer and earns US$3 per day as well. This couple has five children, two of who are students and three of who are garment factory workers. Varn N. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer so that her husband can help her transport vegetables to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables.

loans.name: Temple Of God Group

texts.en: Mary is seventy-one years old. She is widowed and has given birth to nine children, some of who are still in school. She lives with some of her children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Mary is a food vendor. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Temple of God. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best of education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to expand businesses.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet A. is 40 years old and married with four children. Her children are excelling in school. Her husband is a government worker. Juliet owns a beauty salon where she creates lovely hair styles for her customers. She also sells hair products like shampoo, hair cream and hair extensions. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is popularly called Madam Juliet in her community in Benin City, Edo State.

LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Juliet is a LAPO client requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more salon products to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future. Juliet says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To stock up on more salon products to sell.

loans.name: Vet

texts.en: Vet Y., 35, lives in the Takeo province with her husband and three children. To earn a living, she has been selling fish at the local market to earn approximately US$7 of profit per day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and makes US$3 a day. Vet Y. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to replace her husband's old and unreliable motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an unreliable motorbike.

loans.name: Abua

texts.en:
Abua L. is currently in the business of selling food in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more tables and chairs in order to seat more customers. Abua is 29 years old and is married with a husband that is a driver. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more tables and chairs in order to seat more customers.

loans.name: Leab

texts.en: Leab L., 24, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She raises pigs and earns US$1 of profit a day while her husband is a moto-taxi driver. On average, he makes US$4 of profit a day. This couple has two young children. Leab L. would like to take out a loan of US$700 to replace her husband's old and unreliable motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann S. is 30 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker and is able to make about US$2.50 of profit a day while her husband is a moto-taxi driver and makes about US$3 per day. This couple has one young child. Vann S. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to replace her husband's old and unreliable motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Mrs. Tep P., age 36, is married with three school-aged children. She currently stays at home to take care of the children and household. Her husband’s income as a taxi driver supports their family. 

Because Tep P. doesn’t have a job, she is requesting a loan of 700 USD to be used to finance selling groceries in front of her home. The loan will allow her to contribute to the family’s income and so raise their standard of living. (Tep P. was not available on the day her photograph was to be taken, so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To finance selling groceries in front of her home.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian P. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and potatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to buy other items like rice, beans, and maize flour to sell. Lilian is 24 years old and is married with a husband that is a prison officer. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy other items like rice, beans, and maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Jah Bless Group

texts.en: Charlotte is forty-nine years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. She is a fish seller. Charlotte is the leader of a trust bank group called Jah Bless. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests for a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best of education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy goods to expand their businesses.

loans.name: Phart

texts.en: Phart L., 28, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typicalL. make US$2 of profit a day. They also make and sell cow rope halters. This couple has two young children. Phart L. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase rope so that she and her husband can make cow rope halters to sell.

loans.use: To buy rope for cow rope halters.

loans.name: Samaria Group

texts.en: Mary is fifty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to five children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Mary is a trader in utensils. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Samaria. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests for a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to expand businesses.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem T. is 42 years old and resides with her husband in the Takeo province. She makes and sells Khmer cake at the local market and is able to make a living of US$12 in revenue each day. Her husband stays at home helps his wife make cake. This couple has five children, four of who are students and one who is a motorbike mechanic. Sem T. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase rice and other ingredients so that she can make more cake to sell.

loans.use: To purchase rice and other ingredients.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda A. is from the village of Lugait, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Linda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Linda owns and operates a business in the retail sector--a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Linda has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Linda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Linda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Linda is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Linda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Timothy Ngigi

texts.en:
Timothy is 40 years old and married with five children. He operates a small canteen on a company's property, selling food to the company's employees. He has been in business for a period of about one year with a profit of approximately 150,000 Kenya shillings a month. Some of the things he sells in his canteen include a cup of tea, snacks to take with tea, and some easy-to-make meals.

He has never borrowed from another MFI and was introduced to KADET by a friend. He wants to use the loan to expand the canteen and also open a shop at the same place to meet all the needs of his customers.

He hopes to operate a larger canteen and buy enough stock for the shop to supply all the items required by his customers.

loans.use: To expand his canteen and open a shop.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is thirty-one years old. She is married and has given birth to two children. Both are in school. She lives with the children and her husband in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Sarah trades in second-hand clothes. She buys from Accra and hawks to sell in her community. She also treks to sell in nearby communities. She has been in business for over twelve years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to expand businesses.

loans.name: Louella

texts.en:
Louella B. is from the village of Lugait, Misamis oriental. She is 26 years old. Louella is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Louella owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling dressed chicken and fish in the local community. Louella has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Louella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Louella is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Louella from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Calvary Praise Group

texts.en: Margaret is twenty-three years old. She is single but has one child who is in school. She lives with her child in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Margaret is a fish seller. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Calvary Praise. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to expand businesses.

loans.name: Naqra Hama Group

texts.en:
This is the Naqra Hama group. This group is made up of three members.

Hama is the group leader. She is about 40 years old, married and has 6 children. She wants to take a loan for her quilting business to buy necessary materials for her business.

The second member is Hamida. She wants to receive a loan for her tailoring business. With the loan she can grow her business and buy a new (sewing) machine for her business. 

The last member of the group is N. Ahmad. He wants to take a loan for his business selling mobile phones in his shop. With the loan he wants to expand his business and buy the required materials for his shop.

Together, they have requested a group loan of 30000 AFN to change the status of their businesses and their lives. They would like to commend this effective process.

loans.use: expand and progress for their business

loans.name: Pure Joy Group

texts.en: Bernice is twenty-three years old. She is single but has one child who has yet to start school. She lives with her child in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Bernice is a fish seller. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Pure Joy. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests for a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to expand businesses.

loans.name: Suy

texts.en: Suy K. is 54 years old and lives with his wife in the Takeo province. He is a cow dealer who is able to make a living of US$8 in revenue each day, while his wife is a farmer and makes US$1 per day. This couple lives with one child. Suy K. is asking for a loan of US$500. He needs to purchase cows to resell.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Garden Of Eden Group

texts.en: Rebecca is thirty–eight years old. She is married and has given birth to three children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Takoradi. Takoradi is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation in the region. Rebecca runs a pharmaceutical store in the community. Rebecca is constrained by funds to run the business. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Garden of Eden. All the members are engaged in trading. They work so hard to put food on the table of their households and also support their kids in school. They believe the loan will help them to be more resourced to purchase food ingredients and stocks in bulk and in time to serve their customers. They believe your support would enable them grow their business.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk.

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Say P., 44, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She grows and sells vegetables at the local market to earn a living. She is able to make about US$4.50 of profit every day, while her husband, who is a moto-taxi driver, is able to make US$8 in revenue a day. This couple has five children: two of whom are students and three of whom are employed to help raise the standard of living. Say P. is asking for a loan of US$800 to make a new investment. She will use this money to invest in a fruit stand.

loans.use: To invest in a fruit stand.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina is thirty-six years old. She is divorced and has one child in school. She lives with her child in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana and fishing is the major occupation of the people there.

Faustina is a seamstress by profession and has four apprentices in training. She wants a loan to buy many kinds of fabrics and other sewing accessories to be able to better serve her clients. Faustina has been in business for ten years.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and sewing accessories

loans.name: Qalame Dine Group

texts.en:
Adelah is 36 years old. She has four children who are in school. She is the group leader of Qalame Dine group. There are four members in this group.

Adelah wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. With this loan she wants to buy a new (sewing) machine and disk for her business. 

Ahamd Sha and M. Sha want to take a loan for their metal shop business. They need this loan because they want to expand and progress their business.

Kamelah wants to take a loan for her beading business. She needs to buy necessary materials. 

They request a group loan of 40000 AFN. They want to thank all lenders to AFSG and the Kiva process in Afghanistan. They are thankful that they help the poor people of this country.

loans.use: Expand their businesses.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is fifty-one years old. She is married and has four children who are all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana and fishing is the major occupation of the people there.

Grace is a trader. She trades food items such as maize, cassava, etc. She buys these items from nearby communities and treks to sell them in other nearby towns. She has been a trader for ten years and wants a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy food items to trade

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena is forty years old and married with four children. All of her children are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community called Axim in the western region of Ghana.

Philomena works hard to support her husband in providing for the family. She trades cereals such as beans, maize, and rice and supplies them to retailers and food vendors in her community. Philomena also treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for over twelve years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Antioch Group

texts.en:
Comfort is thirty-four years old and married with four children. All of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Takoradi, which is along the coast in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people there. 

Comfort is a fish monger. She makes income mainly from this businesses to support her family. She is the leader of a village trust bank group called Antioch. The members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through these businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock in bulk to avoid price hikes and also cut down on frequent travels. They are expecting to make higher profits this season to help pay their kids school fees. Your support would enable them grow their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock in bulk.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 38 years old and married with a child. Her child is still dependent on her and goes to school. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Esther sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her stall. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits during this season.

Esther is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.

Esther is requesting a loan amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: St. Theresa Group

texts.en:
Belinda is twenty–two years old. She is single and has one child who is in school. She lives with her child in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana and the main occupation in this area is fishing businesses.

Belinda runs a store in the community. She is the leader of a trust bank group called St. Theresa and the members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Atta

texts.en: Atta is a forty-three year old married man with four unemployed children. He has owned a restaurant in his town since 1995 and serves delicious Lebanese food there. Atta is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy food products and to make some renovations to his restaurant.

loans.use: Buy food products and make restaurant renovations

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is thirty–eight years old. She has no children and lives with her husband in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coast in the western region of Ghana and the major occupation of people in this area is fishing businesses.

Hannah is a seamstress by profession and has three apprentices who are currently in training. She wants a loan to buy many kinds of fabrics and other sewing accessories to be able to better serve her clients. In addition, Hannah also sells provisions on a table top in front of her workshop. She has been in business for eight years.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and sewing accessories

loans.name: Tabitha Group

texts.en:
Josephine is thirty–eight years old. She is married and has three children in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Takoradi. Takoradi is along the coast in the western region of Ghana and the major occupation of the people in this area is fishing businesses.

Josephine is a fish monger. She makes income mainly from this business to support her family. She is the leader of a village trust bank group called Tabitha. The members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through these businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock in bulk to avoid price hikes and also cut down on frequent travels. They are expecting to make higher profits this season to help pay their kids school fees. Your support would enable them grow their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy stock in bulk.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is forty–three years old and married with three children. All of her children are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community called Axim in the western region of Ghana. She works hard to support her husband in providing for their family.

Cecilia runs a pharmaceutical shop in her community and sells all kinds of tablets and syrups. She has her drug store by the roadside in her community. Cecilia has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase her stock. It is her desire to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy pharmaceutical drugs

loans.name: Ophelia

texts.en:
Ophelia is forty years old and married with three children. All of her children are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community called Axim in the western region of Ghana. Ophelia works hard to support her husband in providing for their family.

She trades in secondhand clothes for both males and females. Ophelia sell these clothes in her community and also treks to nearby communities to sell. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothes

loans.name: Fati

texts.en:
Fati is forty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community called Axim in the Western Region of Ghana.

Fati works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She trades in cereals such as beans, maize, rice, etc., and supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. She also treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is currently in the business of selling ice cream, charcoal, and bread and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.  

Mary is 36 years old and married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 3 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bakery.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is also known as Mama Linda in her community in Benin City in the State of Edo in Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs like rice, beans, onions, melons and cooking oil. She loves this business because of the profits. She is 38 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a police officer and he also supports their household. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.  She needs a loan amount of NGN 40,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Aisha is forty two years old. She is married and has five children who are all currently in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Aisha is a trader. She trades in textile materials. She says she wants a loan to buy many kinds of textile materials. She sells in her community and treks to other nearby communities to sell on their market days. Aisha has been in business for three years.

loans.use: To buy textile materials.

loans.name: Yulia

texts.en:
Yulia is married with one child. She rents some space at a department store in Novomoskovsk town and sells men's clothing, jeans, hats, etc. Her profit is about 4,000 UAH per month.

Yulia started this business 12 years ago. During this time her business has become a stable source of income for her family. Yulia is an active, hardworking, and entrepreneurial person. She is always looking for something new and fresh to satisfy customer demand. Yulia lives with her husband and son in a small apartment.

Yulia would like to borrow 16,400 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventories. She hopes to receive additional profits and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Leh We Try Group

texts.en:
Bintu K. on the left in the photo above is the leader of this group. This group of borrowers named their group 'Leh We Try', a Krio phrase meaning 'Let Us Try'. They are residing and doing business in Waterloo, a small town. They have come to SMT, a partner of 'Shine on Sierra Leone' in Waterloo to apply for a loan of SLL 2,400,000 (or SLL 800,000 each). With this loan, the group of borrowers will buy more goods to expand their businesses.

The leader of the group, Bintu, was born in Freetown and is married to a professional worker and they have one child who is in class four. Bintu sells market food – peppers, onions, Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), etc. Bintu also owns a kiosk where she sells cigarettes, soft drinks, sardines, and many other items. The twenty-seven-year-old has been running this business for almost ten years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy cartons of sardines, Peak milk, and gallons of palm-oil.

loans.use: Buy cartons of sardines, Peak milk, and gallons of palm-oil to sell

loans.name: Hanim

texts.en:
Hanim A. is currently in the business of selling beans, tomatoes, and rice. She is requesting a loan to purchase dried and fresh fish to sell. Hanim is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a teacher. She has 4 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase dried and fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Eki

texts.en:
Eki rears chickens to make a living. She also sells eggs. She is 54 years old and married with eight children. She has been in her business for a long time. She says her major challenge is insufficient capital to expand her business. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more chickens to rear and sell.

Eki is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens to sell

loans.name: Old Timers Group

texts.en:
Francis P. is the leader of a group of two borrowers called Old Timers Group. He is 54 years old and is married with seven children aged 13 - 32 years, their educational levels 6th grade- university student and some high school dropouts. He also cares for a nephew.

Francis is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to poverty. He and his family live on the Selega Road and he sells in the Voinjama central market, Voinjama city, the capital of Lofa County, northern Liberia.

Francis’ business is the sale of general goods. He buys general goods wholesale and sells retail in a shop at the Voinjama central market. He has been running this business for four years, and is hoping to improve his shop business to a better one. He approaches his customers in a good manner and gives good customer service in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him.

Francis needs this loan to purchase more cosmetics, body cream and fish to serve customers. He dreams of supporting his children and giving them a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics, body cream and fish to serve customers

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 31 years old and married with two children, one of whom is attending school. He runs the Kiragu Retail Shop and sells a variety of household goods. He's been in business for five years and has successfully completed a previous loan for Kes. 35,000 through Faulu. He is now requesting Kes. 50,000 to increase the stock of household goods in his shop.

In the future, Joseph would like to own land for both a home and his business. He says that in Faulu he has learned how to keep business records and he feels optimistic that he can improve his standard of living and expand his business.

Joseph's wife is depicted on the profile photo at the Kiragu Retail Shop.

loans.use: To buy stock of household products

loans.name: Hope To God Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu C. on the left of the photo above is the leader of this group. This group of borrowers named their group 'Hope to God'. They are residing and doing business in Waterloo, a small town. They have come to SMT, a partner of 'Shine on Sierra Leone' in Waterloo to apply for a loan of SLL 1,400,000. With this loan, this group of borrowers will buy more goods to expand their businesses.

The leader of the group was born in Lunsar, in northern Sierra Leone. But she now lives in Waterloo, together with her husband and children. Her husband too is a businessman; three of her children are attending secondary school and four are adults. The forty-nine-year-old sells ginger, fertilizer, green seeds, beans and several items common to West Africans (what we call here Yoruba market).

Kadiatu has been doing this type of business for three years; prior to this she was selling peppers. With her share of this loan, Kadiatu will buy one bag of fertilizer, three bags of salt, and two bags of ginger.

loans.use: Buy one bag of fertilizer, three bags of salt, and two bags of ginger.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a fashion designer. She makes lovely Nigerian designs for her customers and she also sells colorful sarongs. She loves her business because it involves skills and innovation. She is 38 years old and married with five children. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. She is a very hardworking woman and she helps her husband in meeting the basic needs of her family. She needs a loan of 60,000 nairas to purchase more sarongs to sell. 
She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Susanian

texts.en:
Susanian K. sells maize flour in the market and is requesting a loan to buy bags of onions and more flour to sell. Susanian is 37 years old and is married to a soldier. She has four children who are all in school. With the profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a maize flour store.

About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of onions and more flour to sell

loans.name: Abiba

texts.en: Abiba is twenty–nine years old. She is divorced and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Takoradi. Takoradi is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people in the region. Abiba is a trader. She trades in textile materials. She does her selling through "hawking" (door-to-door selling)and also treks to nearby communities to sell on market days. She wants a loan to buy textile materials in bulk. Abiba has been in business for three years and she believes your support would enable her to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy textile materials.

loans.name: Galilee Group

texts.en: Beatrice is twenty–six years old. She is married and has given birth to two children who are both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Takoradi. Takoradi is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people in the region. Beatrice is a food vendor. She makes income mainly from this business to support her family. She is the leader of a village trust bank group called Galilee. The members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through these businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock in bulk to avoid price hikes and also cut down on frequent travels. They are expecting to make higher profits this season to help pay their kids school fees. Your support would enable them grow their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bullk.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa S. sells provisions such as biscuits, canned tomatoes and so on at Broyinbima near Abura. Theresa has studied through senior high school.  She is single and has three children. Theresa has been selling provisions since 2000. She spends her income in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house for the family. She is therefore saving towards the building of the family house.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Two Christian Business Partner Group

texts.en:
Mohammed D. is a leader of a group of two borrowers called Two Christian business partner. He is 51 years old and is married with 4 children between 1 and 11 years old.  They range in school from kindergarten through 7th grade.

Mohammed is a high school graduate but was not able to attend university due to poverty.
He and his family live and work in the Telboma neighborhood of Voinjama, the capital city of Lofa in northern Liberia.

His runs a local pharmacy.  He buys goods wholesale and resells to residents of his community.
Mohammed has been running this business for 4 years, and hopes to improve his business from a small shop to a bigger pharmacy.
He is friendly with his community in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him.

Mohammed needs this loan to purchase additional medicine to increase his inventory as he has been facing financial challenges with his pharmacy.

He dreams of giving his children the best support through education.

loans.use: to purchase additional medicine to increase inventory

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica B. sells maize, and other provisions at Ensukye near Abura.  Monica has no educational background.  She is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a teacher. Monica has been selling maize and other provisions since 1990. She supports her family by paying school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica D. is currently in the business of selling bread at home and is requesting a loan to purchase more bread and cakes to sell.  Monica is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a driver. She has 2 school age children.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bread and cakes to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a trader and she sells foodstuffs such as rice, yam, beans and cooking oil at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business since 2004. She sells for long hours to support her family. Mary sells her foodstuffs at the market and at home. She is 40 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a mechanic and he also supports the family. She needs a loan of 60,000 nairas to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. 
She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Inna

texts.en:
Inna is married with two children. She has a business that sells various kind of food. She started this business 15 years ago with one small table at the market. Today Inna has two kiosks at the market and a small store that sells food items in bulk for other vendors. Inna has very strong entrepreneurial skills. Her business story is a great example for her friends and colleagues to follow.

Inna would like to borrow 14,700 UAH to increase the assortment of food she sells. She hopes to increase her sales during the coming Christmas season.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of food to sell

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
These are borrowers in the small town of Waterloo, twenty-two miles from Freetown. They are a petty traders who want a loan of SLL 1,400,000 to enable them to further expand their businesses. With a loan, they will add more goods to their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living.

On the left of the photo is Kadiatu Conteh. The 29-year-old is the leader of this group. She was born in Waterloo, is married and has two children and fosters two more children. All of these children are attending school but one, who is in nursery school.

For more than ten years now, Kadiatu has been selling oil, rice, Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), shrimp, and plastic bags. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by adding bags of rice, gallons of oil and palm-oil to it.

loans.use: adding bags of rice, gallons of oil and palm-oil

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba M. sells palm oil, tomatoes and vegetables at a market near Abura. Aba has no educational background. She is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a farmer. 

Aba has been selling palm oil, tomatoes and vegetables since 1990. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy tomatoes, palm oil and vegetables for sale. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy tomatoes, palm oil and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Fairness #3 Group

texts.en:
Tarnue S. S. is the leader of a group of borrowers called Fairness #3. He is 32 years old and is married with a 7-year-old child, who is in 4th grade. Tarnue is a university student.

He and his family live in the Buzzie Quarter community and work on Margeret Street in Voinjama city, the capital of Lofa county in northern Liberia. His business is the sale of petroleum. He buys gas and fuel from wholesalers and sells retail to drivers in Voinjama.

Tarnue has been running this business for two years and is hoping to improve his business to a petroleum station in the near future. He offers good service to his customers in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him.

Tarnue needs this loan to purchase more gas and fuel to improve business. He has been facing financial constraints over the years with his business. Tarnue dreams of being a help to his kid and the rest of his family.

loans.use: To purchase more gas and fuel to improve business

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is 42 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a contractor and he also supports the home. She sells foodstuffs like rice, beans and cooking oil. Helen is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is requesting a loan for the amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Simon Ngatia

texts.en: Simon, has operated the Simrut General Shop in the Utawal Estate for the last seven months.  He sells home products and cereals, including flour, sugar, cooking oil, rice, sodas, snacks and poultry feed.  He has one employee and considers his business challenges to be lack of funds  and strong competition.  He is using the proceeds of this KES20,000 loan to restock the shop.  In addition to the store, Simon works as a property agent.  His goal in life is to become a wholesaler.  Simon is married and describes himself as hardworking and disciplined.

loans.use: 2 sacks of sugar and rice, 3 bags of poultry feed, 4 bales of flour and 40 mobile phone cards

loans.name: Sama

texts.en:
Sama E. is currently in the business of selling food, beer and sodas in a hotel and is requesting a loan to buy Jerry cans of cooking oil and tomatoes to sell.

Sama is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a carpenter. She has 5 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up another hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy Jerry cans of cooking oil and tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Since 1998, Vivian F. has been selling tomatoes, onions, okro (okra), garden eggs (eggplant) and so on. She currently sells at the new market near Abura. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

Vivian has no educational background. She is married and has five dependents.

Vivian’s loan will be used to buy more tomatoes, onions and okro for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, onions and okro for sale

loans.name: Good People Group

texts.en:
Theresa D. is a leader of a group of two borrowers called Good People. She is 29 years old and is single with an 11 years old child, and the child’s educational level is 5th grade. Theresa is a 5th grade drop-out due to lack of financial support.

She and her child lives and work in the Sheriff Quarter, Voinjama city the capital of Lofa county, northern Liberia.  Her business is beauty salon. She offers services like fixing hair, nails, facial and more to residents of her  community in  Voinjama city.

Theresa has been running this business for 3 years, and hoping to improve by having another salon at a different location in the near future.  She offers good service to her customers and talks to them in a good manner in order to encourage customers to continue patronizing her business.  Theresa needs this loan to purchase some hair extensions and new kinds of goods to improve business: her illness for about 3 months declined the business.  She dreams of supporting her kid with better education.

loans.use: To purchase some hair extensions and new goods for a beauty salon.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 42 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a commercial driver and also a welder and he also supports the home. She sells foodstuffs like rice, beans and cooking oil. Patience is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is requesting a loan for the amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for to sell

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei sells men's clothing at the central market in Melitopol town. He's been in this business for six years. His kiosk has a good location, and he offers affordable prices and a large assortment. All these factors help Sergei run his business successfully. Sergei would like to borrow 7,500 hryvnia to purchase more inventory.

Sergei is married. He hopes to make additional income to continue fixing the house where he and his wife live.

loans.use: To  purchase more inventory

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina trades in cereals such as beans, maize, rice, etc. She supplies retailers and food vendors in her community. Paulina also treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for nine years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

Paulina is 42 years old. She is married and has two children who are both still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community called Axim in the western region of Ghana. Paulina works hard to help her husband provide for the family.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Tièssiri sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans et 5 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Dioïla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Ces femmes ont intégré  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité d’articles divers  tels, les produits manufacturés, les céréales, les condiments alimentaires etc. La plupart des articles sont achetés à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et les céréales sont achetées sur place et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont revendues sur place au marché de Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 20.000FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Tièssiri group are married women who are, on average, 41 years old with 5 children. With their husband and children they live in large traditional families in the town of Dioïla, which lies in the prefecture of Dioïla, in the region of Koulikoro in the Republic of Mali; They met through neighbors and relatives. These women have joined the microfinance company, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of keeping their profitable business going. They are on their third group loan and all their previous loans have been repaid punctually. With this loan they are planning to buy a large quantity of miscellaneous products such as manufactured products, cereals, condiments etc...The majority of the items are bought at Barnako (capital of Mali) and the cereals are bought locally and in surrounding villages. The goods are sold on locally at the market in Dioïla to a customer base made up of women and men. They are expecting to make a monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA each. The profits will be partly reinvested in their business and partly used for the families' daily expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Ariel

texts.es:
El señor Ariel P. C. tiene 28 años y vive en la zona de Maica Chica en la zona Sud de la ciudad de Cochabamba. Ariel recién se caso hace solo unos meses y viven en casa de su madre, puesto que aun no tienen  dinero para una casa propia. En esta casa es donde tiene 4 vacas lecheras que fueron la herencia que le dio su mama cuando el cumplió los 18 años.

Ariel se dedica a la cría de ganado lechero mejorado, que es un trabajo que su familia hace desde hace muchas generaciones. Gracias al buen manejo del ganado la pequeña granja que tiene es conocida en la zona por la buena calidad de la leche que produce. Ahora que tiene el apoyo de su esposa Ariel asiste a un instituto en las noches para aprender mecánica automotriz y así poder algún día abrir un taller mecánico.  

El crédito será utilizado para construir corrales para alojar ganado. Esta es la época donde empiezan las lluvias en la ciudad de Cochabamba y es un problema para las vacas cuando no tienen refugio, por esa razón es que Ariel quiere construir los Corrales para que sus vacas no sufran las tempestades de la lluvia. Al tener un refugio las vacas no tendrán problemas de ninguna índole y por ende no bajaran su producción de leche, entonces los ingresos de Ariel no disminuirán. El mayor sueño de Ariel es hacer crecer su granja lechera y abrir una mecánica automotriz que es un hobby que a él le gusta mucho.
texts.en:
Ariel P. C. is 28. He lives in the Maica Chica area south of the city of Cochabamba. Ariel got married a few months ago. They live in his mother’s house because they do not have enough money for their own house. At this house he has the four dairy cows that were an inheritance his mother gave him when he turned 18. Ariel raises dairy cows. It is work that has been in his family for many generations. Thanks to good cattle management, their small farm is well known in the area for the good quality of milk it produces. Now that he has help from his wife, Ariel goes to an institution in the evenings to learn auto mechanics. That way he will one day be able to open a mechanic’s shop. The loan is to build corrals to house the cattle. This is the season when the rains start in the city of Cochabamba. It is a problem for the cows when they do not have refuge. That is why Ariel wants to build the corrals, so that the cows do not suffer from the rain storms. By having a refuge, the cows will not have any problems. Therefore, milk production will not decrease. Ariel’s dream is to make his dairy farm grow and to open an auto mechanic shop, which is a hobby that he really likes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build corrals to house livestock

loans.name: Nyadid

texts.en:
Nyadid M. is currently in the business of selling various items in a shop such as rice,sugar,salt,soap, etc. and is requesting a loan to stock up on more items for her retail shop.  Nyadid is 35 years old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a wholesale shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Replenish more items for her retail shop

loans.name: Believe Usef Ii Group

texts.en:
