These are a group of petty traders in the small town of Waterloo which is about twenty-two miles from Freetown. These entrepreneurs are seeking a loan of SLL 1,500,000 to enable them to expand their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and earn more profit so that they can better support themselves and their families. 

The leader of this group of borrowers is Adama K. in the middle of the photo. Adama is thirty-seven years of age, born in Waterloo. She is married to a soldier and they have four children. Her children are attending school, two in secondary school, one in primary school and one in nursery school. Adam has been a businesswoman for more than fifteen years now. She sells dried fish. With her share of this loan, she will buy as many baskets of fish as the loan and her current business capital combined will permit. A basket of fish costs something between SLL 500,000 to SLL 700,000.

loans.use: Buy baskets of dried fish

loans.name: Happy Sisters Group

texts.en:
Saybah C. is a leader of a group of two borrowers called Happy Sisters. She is 38 years old and is married with 3 children aged 9-18 years old, and one has an educational level of 7th grade and the rest drop-outs.

Saybah is not literate, due to poverty.

She and her family live in the Buzzie quarter and work in central Voinjama city, the capital of Lofa county, northern Liberia .

Her business is a bar and restaurant. She sells prepared food and drinks to NGO workers in central Voinjama, in Voinjama city, Lofa county, Liberia. Saybah has been running this business for 8 years, and hoping to improve by having a bigger restaurant in the near future. She serves her customers with good manners in order to encourage them to continue patronizing her business. 

Saybah needs this loan to purchase rice, drinks, oil and more ingredients to improve her business. 

She dreams of building a house of her own.

loans.use: To purchase rice, drinks, oil and more to improve business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia is thirty years old. She is divorced and has given birth to one child who is in school. She lives with her child in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana.

Fishing business is the major occupation of the people. Leticia is a trader. She trades in ready-made clothes for both men and women. She sells her wares near and far. She buys from Accra. Leticia has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to expand it.

loans.use: To buy ready-made clothes

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fantombougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de commerce. 
Elles collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, elles achèteront,  une grande quantité de différentes sortes de condiments alimentaires, des céréales et des habillements. 
Les condiments et les habillements sont achetés en gros à Bamako et les céréales sont achetées aux environs du village et le tout  est revendu au marché de Fana  au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de  35.000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre  la nourriture, la santé et la réutilisation dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of Benkadi Group are married women who, on average, are 38 years old and have four children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families in the village of Fantombougou, subprefecture of Fana, in the region of Koulikoro of the Republic of Mali. They have known each other through neighborhood and business links.

They joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure a continuous financial support to their activities. This is their seventh solidarity loan. They have repaid all their previous loans on schedule.

As regards this new loan, the group members will buy a large quantity of food condiments, cereals and clothes. The condiments and clothes will be bought wholesale in Bamako, whereas the cereals will be bought in the surrounding countryside. They will resell all this at the market in Fana, located next to the tarred road, to a clientele made up of women and men.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 CFA francs each. They will spend part of their profit on food and healthcare and reinvest part of it in their businesses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments, cereals and clothes

loans.name: Benta

texts.en: Benta A. runs two businesses. The first is a small green grocery kiosk and the second is the Mvulimivu Hair Salon, where she offers plaiting, weaving, applying treatment and retouching. Her business challenges are managing water shortages and the ups and downs in customer demands. She is using the loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings to restock her green grocery kiosk. Benta is married to a day laborer and the couple has two daughters and one son. She describes herself as a well-rounded lady who is polite and cooperative. She dreams of seeing her children complete university education, owning a home and meeting her family's needs without much hassle.

loans.use: To restock her green grocery kiosk

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is married with 2 children and she is 45 years old. Her husband is a photographer and he also supports the home. She owns a grocery store where she sells groceries like biscuits, milk, soap, drinks and canned foods. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekafo sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fantombougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de commerce. 
Elles collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles  comptent acheter,  une grande quantité de céréales et des condiments alimentaires. 
Les condiments sont achetés le plus souvent en gros à Bamako et les céréales sont achetées dans le village et environnants et  le tout est revendu au marché aux clients venant de Bamako pour les céréales et aux résidents pour les condiments alimentaires.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 50.000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture,  la santé et  les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Djekafo group are married women of an average age of 46, with an average of four children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families in the village of Fantombougou, in the subprefecture of Fana,which is found in the Koulikoro region of the Republic of Mali. They met through neighbours and through their business activities. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation in the hope of having constant financial support for their business activities. The women are on their tenth group loan and all previous ones have been successfully repaid. They intend to use their new loan in order to buy a large volume of cereals and food condiments. The condiments are usually bought in bulk at the Bamako market, and the cereals are bought from the village and neighbouring areas. Everything is sold at the market to customers who come from Bamako for their cereals, and condiments are sold to local residents. The women hope to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA each; profits are distributed between food, health and business activities.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals and condiments.

loans.name: Monday

texts.en: Monday is a transporter. He owns a motorcycle used for commercial purposes to convey his passengers from one location to another in his community. Monday also has a school. He made his wife the head teacher of the school. When the school closes for the day he rests for a while before using his motorcycle for commercial purposes. He is married with three children and he is 46 years old. Monday is a hard working man and he hopes to lift his business above poverty. He is requesting a loan amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more textbooks and school uniforms. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more textbooks and school uniforms

loans.name: Wonders Of God Group

texts.en: Grace is forty eight years old. She is widowed and has four children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Grace is a food vendor. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Wonders of God. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Kafotatoala Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Kafotatoala sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 25 ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fantombougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de commerce. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles viennent tout juste de commencer la collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles comptent utiliser le prêt pour acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et des habillements. Les produits sont achetés au marché de Fana et revendus sur place au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 15.500F CFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture,  la santé et  les  activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Kafotatoala group are married women who average 25-years-old with 2 children. With their husband and children, they live in large traditional families in Fantombougou village, in the Fana district, Koulikoro region, of Mali. They know each other through neighbor and work connections. They collaborate with the microfincance institution Soro Yiriwaso, taking care to always have financial support for their activities. They all just began working with Soro Yiriwaso.

They count on using the loan to buy a large amount of food condiments and clothing apparel. The products are purchased at the Fana market and resold on location at the market and on the street to both male and female clients. They estimate that each will earn a monthly profit of 15,500 FCFA. The profits are shared and go toward food, health and activities.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments and clothing

loans.name: Khudiar

texts.en:
Khudiar R. is currently in the business of selling local beer and groundnut paste. She is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer and more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell. Khudiar is 45 years old and is married with a husband who is a driver. She has 7 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock crates of beer and more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell.

loans.name: Saniya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Saniya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fantombougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de commerce. 
Elles collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation de ce nouveau prêt, elles  comptent acheter, une grande quantité de tubercules auprès des revendeurs venant de Sikasso, des condiments alimentaires  en gros à Bamako pour la restauration. 
Elles effectuent leurs ventes  sur place au marché de Fana et au bord du goudron à la sortie de la ville (au niveau du poste de contrôle) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de  45.000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture,  la santé et  les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Saniya group are married women who average 35-years-old with 3 children. With their husband and children, they live in large traditional families in the Fantomougou village, in the Fana district of the Mali Republic. They know each other through neighbor and work connections. They collaborate with the microfincance institution Soro Yiriwaso, taking care to always have financial support for their activities. They are on their tenth loan together and have repaid all of their previous loans in full. With this new loan, they count on buying a large quantity of tubers from vendors in Sikasso and wholesale food condiments in Bamako for catering. They make their sales at the Fana market and on the sidewalk at the edge of the village (at the border control checkpoint) to both male and female customers.They estimate making a monthly profit of 45,000 FCFA. The profits are shared and go toward food, health, and social activities.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tubers and condiments

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Believe in God' group. Members of the 'Believe in God' group are petty traders in the small town of Waterloo, near Freetown. This group of entrepreneurs sell different types of commodities and have been in business for many years. However, their businesses have been growing at a very slow pace. They thus formed themselves into a group of three and applied for a loan of SLL 2,400,000 from SMT, a partner of 'Shine on Sierra Leone' in Waterloo.

The leader of the group is Ramatu J. on the left in the photo. Ramatu was born in Barsa town, Waterloo. She is fifty-two years of age. She is married and has seven children. Her husband is a farmer and three of her children are attending secondary school. For nearly twenty years now, Ramatu has been selling cottons, beans, oil, butter, rice, onion, Maggi (used in sauce), and so on. Ramatu wants a loan in order to expand her business. She will use her share of the loan to buy five lengths of cotton, five gallons of oil, one bag of beans and one packet of Maggi.

loans.use: To buy five lengths of cotton, five gallons of oil, one bag of beans and one packet of Maggi.

loans.name: Ese

texts.en: Ese is 30 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a brick layer. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school except for the youngest child who is not yet old enough. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.  She sells rechargeable phone cards and groceries to make a living. She needs a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo is 43 years old and married with three children.

He owns a welding business that has been in operation for six years and also earns some extra income through small-scale farming. He successfully repaid a previous loan from Faulu for 35,000 KES. This loan is for 50,000 KES, and he will use the funds to buy more welding materials.

Leo describes himself as hardworking and optimistic and hopes to improve his standard of living by expanding his business. He says that through Faulu, he has learned how to better manage his business and believes that in ten years he will own a very large welding company.

loans.use: To buy welding materials

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 39 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Fantombougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, de commerce.   
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles achèteront une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et des habillements. Les produits sont achetés en gros à Bamako et le tout  est revendu sur place au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 35.000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre la nourriture, la santé et les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group are married women who average 39-years-old and have 4 children. With their husband and children, they live in large, traditional families in Fantombougou village, in the Fana region of Mali. They know each other through neighbor and work connections. They collaborate with the microfincance institution Soro Yiriwaso, taking care to always have financial support for their activities. They are on their third loan together and have repaid all of their previous loans in full. With this new loan, they will buy a large amount of food condiments and clothing apparel. The products are purchased wholesale in Bamako and all resold on location at the market and on the street to both male and female customers. They estimate making a monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA. The profits are shared and go toward food, health, and social activities.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments and clothing

loans.name: Adol

texts.en:
Adol M. is currently in the business of selling beer and charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Adol is 24 years old and is married with a husband who is an accountant. She has one child who is not in school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Micah Group

texts.en: Akua is fifty-two years old. She is divorced and has given birth to five children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Takoradi. Takoradi is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the main occupation of the people there. Akua is a fish monger. She makes income mainly from this business to support her family. She is the leader of a village trust bank group called Micah. The members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through these businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock in bulk to avoid price hikes and also cut down on frequent travels. They are expecting to make higher profits this season to help pay their kids school fees. Your support would enable them grow their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana sells foodstuffs and fruits to make a living. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her immediate family members. She is 57 years old, and married with five children. Her husband works as a security guard in a private firm in Benin City, Edo state. She is a LAPO client. LAPO ("Lift Above Poverty Organization") is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes that her business will grow bigger in order to support her family. She needs a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more fruits and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more fruits and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Philip Harun Obunde

texts.en: Philip Harun Obunde A. runs a welding workshop and sells metal goods such as windows and chairs to schools in Butere and Shiatsala.  He has two employees and has been in this business for the last four years.  His business challenge is competition from similar welding workshops.  He is using the proceeds of KES10,000 to buy materials like metals for making windows and doors.  His goal in life is to have a big workshop in Mumias.  Philip is married and has two children.  He describes himself as hardworking and God-fearing.

loans.use: To buy metals for making windows and doors.

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden H. is currently in the business of selling cooked food in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase crates of beer and sodas to sell.  Kiden is 29 years old and is married with a husband who works as a driver. She has 3 children, all of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build another big restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase crates of beer and sodas to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 40 years old and is married with four children. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also sells building materials to support the home. She sells groceries and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to have a shop in the future through hard work. She has been in this business for a very long time. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Yeno

texts.en:
Yeno B. sells items including salt, books, sugar, beans, and biscuits.  She is requesting a loan to buy bags of rice and beans to sell.  Yeno is 26 years old and is her husband is a business man. She has four children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Future Youths Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'Future Youths' group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the small town of Waterloo, near Freetown. They want to expand their businesses but lack the required capital to enable them to do so. They have thus formed themselves into a group of three and applied to SMT/'Shine on Sierra Leone' for a loan of SLL 500,000 each. With this loan, they can expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. In this way, their living conditions will improve to a new level.

Sulaiman K. on the left in the photo is the leader of this group. Sulaiman was born in Koindu in eastern Sierra Leone. He is married to a businesswoman and they have two children – one in class two and the other not yet of school-going age. Sulaiman sells phones, top-up cards for all the four networks, mobile phone accessories, and he recharges mobile phone batteries for a fee of SLL 1,000. Sulaiman has been doing business for ten – fifteen years now. With this loan, he will be able to expand his business by adding top-up cards, phone batteries and provisions (milk, sugar, butter, mayonnaise etc) to it.

loans.use: Buying top-up cards, phone batteries, and provisions -- milk, sugar, butter, mayonnaise, etc.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing is 43 and is married with two children. Her husband is a printer and also supports the home. Blessing owns a pharmacy where she sells medicine to her customers. She is a friendly woman and she uses her skills to attract more customers to her shop. Blessing has been in this business for a long time. She needs a loan of NGN 60,000 to purchase more medical supplies for her shop. Blessing hopes to own a maternity home in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pharmacutical supplies

loans.name: Ikory

texts.en:
Ikory S. sells tea and bread in a small restaurant.  She is requesting a loan to stock charcoal to sell. Ikory is 28 years old and is a widow.   She has four children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock charcoal to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen owns a beer parlor where she sells drinks and groceries. She is 36 years old, and is married with four children. Her husband is a fashion designer and he also supports the home. Helen makes more sales in the evenings than during the day because that is when her customers return from work and have time to relax with drinks. She needs a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Hijo

texts.en:
Hijo M. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more vegetables and fruit to sell.  Hijo is 44 years old and her husband is a peasant. She has six children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan she plans to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase fresh fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
La señorita Sonia P. C., tiene 22 años de edad y vive a 24 km de la ciudad de Cochabamba en la zona oeste. La señotita Sonia es soltera y vive en la casa de sus padres. En casa de sus padres es donde tiene sus tres vacas lecheras que son su mayor fuente de ingreso.

La señorita Sonia se dedica a la actividad lechera desde muy pequeña. Ya que la familia tiene como actividad principal la produccion de leche y la agricultura, el conocimiento que tiene la cliente sobre la produccion lechera es muy amplio. Al mismo tiempo que se dedica al trabajo de campo ella estudia para profesora en una Universidad Evangelista cerca de su comunidad.

El presente credito sera empleado en la construccion de un criadero de cerdos, esto con la vision de diversificar sus ingresos y contar con una especie de ahorro, ya que la comercializacion de los cerdos se los raliza semestralmente.
texts.en:
Sonia P. C., 22, lives 24 km from the city of Cochabamba in the western area. Sonia is single, and she lives in her parents’ house. Her parents’ house is where she has her three dairy cows. They are her greatest source of income. Sonia has been doing dairy work since she was very small. The family’s primary activities are milk production and agriculture. She has a great deal of knowledge about milk production. She does field work, and she also is studying to be a teacher in the Evangelist University near her community. The current loan will be used to build a pig farm. She has a vision to diversify her income in order to have some kind of savings. She will sell the pigs biannually.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish building a pig farm to start raising pigs

loans.name: Leokadia

texts.en:
Leokadia is 32 years old and sells second-hand clothes. She describes herself as optimistic and visionary and dreams of a bright future. She hopes to improve her standard of living by expanding her business. She says that with Faulu, she has learned how to save and would like to eventually run a wholesale clothing shop. 

She requested this loan from Faulu, a Kiva partner, for 10,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase more stock of used clothing.

loans.use: Increase the stock of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica D.  is currently in the business of selling bread, groundnut paste and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of groundnuts and cooking oil to sell.  Monica is 38 years old and is married with a husband who is a laborer. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase bags of groundnuts and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Ezinabala Group, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Jesca is 40 years old and married with nine children, of which five are still in school. She is a business lady selling food stuffs from Nansagazi trading center. Her biggest business challenges are customers who pay poorly, competition and sometimes a surplus. Amidst all this, Jesca is able to make 50,000/= as profits a week and these help to pay for her children’s school fees and general welfare. She is also able to save and in the future, she will use her savings to buy a boat and start fishing plus build a house for her children. At the moment, Jesca needs a loan to buy more food stuffs for sale in her stall so as to increase production.

loans.use: Buying more food stuffs for resale

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
Rosa A. de 36 años de edad, vive en un sector de escasos servicios básicos ubicado en Paraíso de Guayaquil, su casa es de ladrillos y no esta el camino pavimentado, Rosa comenzó hace 10 años atrás con una canasta vendiendo legumbres y frutas recorriendo varios sectores cercanos de su casa, después con sus pocos ingresos y esfuerzo pudo comprar una carreta que le ayudaría a emprender el negocio que le aseguraría el futuro de su familia.

Hace ya 5 años atrás pudo poner en su casa  una tienda pequeña de víveres en la que puede vender lentejas, fréjol, frutas, arroz, etc. Una de las mayores dificultades de Rosa es cuidar las frutas que no se empolven y por ende traer los víveres de distancias lejanas, con la ayuda de su esposo siendo guardia puede mantener a sus dos hijos de 7 y de 9 años de edad que están en escuelas fiscales cercanas a donde viven.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar mas aceites, jabones, atún, sardinas, para así agrandar mas la tienda, en el futuro quiere surtir la tienda con útiles escolares y así adecuarla mejor a las necesidades de las personas para poder asegurar el futuro de su familia.
texts.en:
Rosa A. is 36. She lives in an area with scant basic services, which is located in Paraíso de Guayaquil. She has a brick house, and the road is not paved. Ten years ago Rosa started selling fruits and vegetables from a basket by traveling to various areas near her house. Later, with her small income and her effort, she was able to buy a cart. The cart would help her establish the business that would assure her family’s future. Five years ago she was able to set up a small grocery store in her house. She sells lentils, kidney beans, fruit, and rice, etc. One of the biggest difficulties Rosa has is taking care of the fruit so that it does not get covered in dust so that she can bring the food from long distances. With help from her husband, a guard, she is able to support her two children. They are seven and nine, and they attend public school near their house. She wants to use the loan to buy more oil, soap, tuna, and sardines to expand her store. In the future she wants to stock her store with school supplies. That way she will better equip it with necessities in order to be able to assure her family’s future.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more oil, soap, tuna, and sardines

loans.name: Faith And Hope Group

texts.en:
Mary T. is a leader of a group of two borrowers called Faith and Hope. She is 39 years old and is married with 3 children aged 5-18 years old. Their educational levels kindergarten-6th grade.
Mary dropped out of elementary school due to poverty.
She and her family lives in central Voinjama, but work in the Central market of Voinjama City, the capital of Lofa county, northern Liberia .
She sells used clothing. She buys used clothes wholesale and sells retail to buyers in the Voinjama central market in Lofa County, Liberia.
Mary has been running this business for 2 years and hopes to improve her business by having a store in the near future.
She serves and treats her customers with care in order to encourage them to continue patronizing her business.
Mary needs this loan to purchase additional used clothes to increase business.
She dreams of giving her family and kids the best support possible.

loans.use: Purchase additional used clothes to increase business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en:
Zeinab P. is currently in the business of selling food in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to buy bread, meat and cooking oil to sell. Zeinab is 28 years old and is married with a husband who is a driver. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy bread, meat and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Abatuuka Group, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Margaret is 30 years old and married with has 2 children and 3 dependents of ages that range from 5 to 17 years. They are all in school. She is a hard-working and determined entrepreneur with a business selling fruits and vegetables in Nile, Njeru. She has been doing so for 13 years and makes 40,000/= in net profit. Margaret says that before the loans, life was a bit hard because she did not have available capital, but now the loans are a big help. She hopes to expand her business by putting up another stall in the market selling the same products or something different depending on the season. She also hopes to build a house and help her children pursue higher levels of education.

loans.use: Purchase more fruits and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Belancille

texts.en:
Belancille is 32 years old and married with four children.  The children are between ten months and eight years old.  Belancille and her family live in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeri, in the northern province of Rwanda, which is approximately two hours' drive from the capital, Kigali.  Belancille has been successfully selling foodstuffs (Irish potatoes) for the last five years. She employs four people from her community and they work from 6AM to 3PM every day except Sunday.

Belancille is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more foodstuffs to sell to her customers.  With this loan, Belancille hopes to improve service to her customers by providing reliable supply and timely delivery of Irish potatoes.  With this strategy, she hopes to realize more profit to reinvest in her business and improve her family’s livelihood.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs like Irish potatoes for resale

loans.name: C3756 Icyerekezo Group

texts.en:
Christine is 44 years old and married with four children aged between 12 and 25. She lives in Nyarugenge district, Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Christine is a skilled businesswoman.  She is the president of a group called Icyerekezo and this is the fifth successful year for the members of this group in the business of selling fish.  Working hours are from 8 AM to 6 PM every day except Sunday. 

After five years in this business, the members of this group are requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase a great quantity of fish for sale.  With this expansion, the members of Icyerekezo hope to attract more customers and to earn more profit. They are hopeful that buying in larger quantities will lead to lower prices and that their customers will benefit because they will get to buy fish at a lower price.  Finally, with any funds not reinvested in their business, the members of Icyerekezo will continue to provide more food (other than fish!) for their children and build a secure future for them.

loans.use: Purchase more fish for sale

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange M. is 22 years old and is married with one child who is two-and-a-half years old. Solange lives in Southern Province, Rwanda, where her shop is located.

Solange sells different kind of product such as shoes, bags, clothes, etc., and has been in business for eight years. Solange’s husband has a monthly income of approximately 20,000 RWF and her own monthly profit is 100,000 RWF before requesting this loan.

Solange is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to purchase more inventory, which will help her to earn more profit. With the extra profit, she hopes to expand her business through purchasing more bags, shoes, clothes, etc. This expansion will allow her to serve more customers.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her shop

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Theogene is 30 years old, is single, and lives in the Eastern Province of Rwanda. He is a self-employed businessman and has sold firewood in bundles for the past eight years. He starts his business early in the morning and finishes late in the evening.

Theogene is now requesting his first loan in order to purchase more trees to be transformed into firewood so that he can satisfy the demand of his customers, especially the restaurant owners. With this loan, he hopes to earn more profits as well as selling to a larger number of customers.

With the profit he expects to gain, Theogene plans to save a portion for his financial stability in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood for sale

loans.name: Tusooka Kwavula Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en: Jane N. is 48 years old and married with four children of ages that range from 10 to 22 years old. They are all in secondary and primary school. She also takes care of her parents. Jane has had a restaurant in the Kitega commercial centre for fifteen years and she is able to make 200,000/= as weekly profits from her food sales. Before opening up a restaurant, Jane was an accountant and her income could not sustain her family like it does today. She says that she is successful because of her loans that help her restock more food stuffs and enable her to buy new utensils. She also has good customer care skills displays her products to her customers. She hopes to become a wholesaler in the future and also hopes to help her children attain higher levels of education. Jane needs a loan to increase her business capital so that she can have a steady supply of products for her customers. She is a very hard-working woman.

loans.use: Purchase more foodstuffs for increased stock.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 60 years old, married and is blessed with ten children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the household. She is a LAPO client. She sells kerosene and groceries at retail prices to her customers in Benin City, Edo state. She hopes to be a major kerosene distributor in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 40,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is 43 years old and she is married with four children. She sells dried beef, popularly called tiko in Nigeria, and she also sells other foodstuffs to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more foodstuffs and dried beef to sell.

Millicent is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried beef and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Tusooka Kwavula Group 2, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Jane is 34 years old and married with five children aged 4-16 years all in secondary and primary schools.  She also takes care of her siblings. Jane has had a retail shop in Nakazadde trading centre for four years and she is able to make 150,000 (local currency) as weekly profits from its sales. She is also a clerk in Scoul ‘a sugar corporation in Lugazi’ thereby being able to have a second income every month. She says that she is successful because of her loans that help her restock as well as the good customer care she offers to her customers.  She hopes to become a wholesaler in the future and to allow her children to pursue a their education. Jane needs a loan to be able to add more capital in her business for a steady supply of products to her customers. She is a very determined lady.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods.
